---
layout: post
title:      "Prevent your Browser from Auto-Reloading"
date:       2020-02-15 23:20:20 +0000
permalink:  prevent_your_browser_from_auto-reloading
---




![](https://code.makery.ch/library/html-css/part1/install-live-server.png)   







While working on a Single Page Application, i had trouble mantaining my page from reloading after every fetch, even though i had told the action to prevent a return.





```
<button data-id=${contractor.id} class="delete" onclick="removeContractor(${contractor.id})"; return false;>Delete</button>

function removeContractor(id){
    //console.log("e", e)
    fetch(`http://localhost:3000/contractors/${id}`, {
        method: "DELETE",
        headers: {
            'Content-Type': 'application/json',
            'Accept': 'application/json'
        }
    })
    .then(document.querySelectorAll(`li a[data-id="${id}"]`)[0].parentElement.remove())
}
```




I spent a day trying to figure out what the problem was, and the solution was so simple, yet i had not considered it. 
There is this great plug in called 'live server' that can be installed in visual studio code. This plug in allows us to launch a HTML page with a server for our browser in our local machine. 





![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)





As great of a functionality as it is, it hinders the process of trully knowing if your page is not reloading. I was building my javascrypt application not knowing if i was executing on my DOM correctly. This live server prevented from activating my CRUD request properly. If you having the same issue, try deleting this live server, or with any similar situations, maybe the answer is right under our nose.
